commit_message:
Add validation for docker registry v2

Validate that Registry is actually up and running.
It's useful to fail early if the registry is for some reasons not
started correctly. It avoids to go further in the deployments steps and
loose time before seeing the failures when deploying containers.

Change-Id: Ic29d1c10741bf946c1df709d14b9b30dcf7f6c9b

subject: container/backend: Always call transform_func when building listings
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 19:22:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-05-21 19:54:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

would love to see the interface request that trips this bit!

something like this should hit it - maybe try and fill in the assertion...

    +    def test_list_objects_iter_prefix_delim_transform(self):
    +        # Test ContainerBroker.list_objects_iter
    +        broker = ContainerBroker(':memory:', account='a', container='c')
    +        broker.initialize(Timestamp('1').internal, 0)
    +
    +        broker.put_object(
    +            '/pets/dogs/1', Timestamp(0).internal, 0,
    +            'text/plain', 'd41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e')
    +        broker.put_object(
    +            '/pets/dogs/2', Timestamp(0).internal, 0,
    +            'text/plain', 'd41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e')
    +        broker.put_object(
    +            '/pets/fish/a', Timestamp(0).internal, 0,
    +            'text/plain', 'd41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e')
    +        broker.put_object(
    +            '/pets/fish/b', Timestamp(0).internal, 0,
    +            'text/plain', 'd41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e')
    +        broker.put_object(
    +            '/pets/fish_info.txt', Timestamp(0).internal, 0,
    +            'text/plain', 'd41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e')
    +        broker.put_object(
    +            '/snakes', Timestamp(0).internal, 0,
    +            'text/plain', 'd41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e')
    +
    +        # def list_objects_iter(self, limit, marker, prefix, delimiter,
    +        #                       path=None, format=None):
    +        listing = broker.list_objects_iter(
    +            100, None, None, '/pets/f', '/',
    +            transform_func=broker._record_to_dict)
    +
    +        self.assertEqual([], list(listing))
    +"}]

(14 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-17 20:19:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

This spec amendment hasn't been updated to reflect the actual code that we've got proposed. The current approach is a lot simpler, IMHO, in that we end up with a consistent data model and far fewer of the sections that explain what is and isn't okay with a record created with a given microversion.

IMHO, we should just plow ahead with the code and update the spec retroactively, but if anyone feels strongly I could re-write this to match what the current approach is."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-17 20:51:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> This spec amendment hasn't been updated to reflect the actual code that we've got proposed. The current approach is a lot simpler, IMHO, in that we end up with a consistent data model and far fewer of the sections that explain what is and isn't okay with a record created with a given microversion.

I haven't looked at the code yet, was hoping to load context by reading the spec first. I will say the if/elif/else/then logic with the API microversion handling in the spec is confusing and I can only imagine it would be complicated in the implementation (and testing). So if there is a simpler way to skin this cat I'm all for that.

> IMHO, we should just plow ahead with the code and update the spec retroactively, but if anyone feels strongly I could re-write this to match what the current approach is.

Again, I'm coming in from the spec first for context, so I'd appreciate having the spec accurately reflect the design being implemented, that way I won't be totally confused when I start reviewing the code."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-17 21:19:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(13 comments)

> This spec amendment hasn't been updated to reflect the actual code that we've got proposed.

Well, it has been updated to remove the implementation details and focus on how the API will behave.  I.e. it mentions nothing about OVOs for consumers, allocations, projects, and users; it mentions nothing about nullable fields or internal sentinels to represent missing values; etc.  As such, I don't think it contradicts anything in either of the proposed code series.

commit_message:
update add-consumer-generation to focus on API

Updates the add-consumer-generation spec to focus strictly on the
behaviour changes expected in the placement API and removing information
about changing consumers.project_id and consumers.user_id fields to be
NULLable.

Change-Id: Iccd0c3214354e7c0d73318a3f728ea321ad32afa
blueprint: add-consumer-generation

Use assertRaises more

It saves us some boilerplate *and* makes tighter assertions about
the type of error.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-20 18:57:08.000000000', 'message': 'Block deleting compute services which are hosting instances

This change makes "DELETE /os-services/{service_id}" fail
with a 409 response when attempting to delete a nova-compute
service which is still hosting instances.

Deleting a compute service also results in deleting the
related compute_nodes table entry for that service host.
The compute node resource provider in placement is tied
to the compute node via the UUID, and if we allow deleting
the compute service and node then the resource provider for
that node is effectively orphaned in Placement, along with
the instances which have allocations against that resource
provider.

Furthermore, restarting the compute service will create a
new service and compute_nodes record, and the compute node
would have a new UUID and resource provider. This will
affect scheduling for that host since Placement will be
reporting it as having available capacity which in reality
is not accurate.

A release note is included for the (justified) behavior
change in the API. A new microversion should not be required
for this since admins should not have to opt out of broken
behavior. Since this API did not previously expect to return
a 409 response, the "expected_errors" decorator is updated
and again, should not require a microversion per the
guidelines:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/microversions.html#when-a-microversion-is-not-needed

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/wsgi/test_services.py

NOTE(mriedem): This is due to the rc_fields move from
change Iea182341f9419cb514a044f76864d6bec60a3683 in Rocky.

Change-Id: I0bd63b655ad3d3d39af8d15c781ce0a45efc8e3a
Closes-Bug: #1763183
(cherry picked from commit 42f62f1ed2ad76829eb9d40a8b9646a523f6381f)
'}]
commit_message:
Block deleting compute services which are hosting instances

This change makes "DELETE /os-services/{service_id}" fail
with a 409 response when attempting to delete a nova-compute
service which is still hosting instances.

Deleting a compute service also results in deleting the
related compute_nodes table entry for that service host.
The compute node resource provider in placement is tied
to the compute node via the UUID, and if we allow deleting
the compute service and node then the resource provider for
that node is effectively orphaned in Placement, along with
the instances which have allocations against that resource
provider.

Furthermore, restarting the compute service will create a
new service and compute_nodes record, and the compute node
would have a new UUID and resource provider. This will
affect scheduling for that host since Placement will be
reporting it as having available capacity which in reality
is not accurate.

A release note is included for the (justified) behavior
change in the API. A new microversion should not be required
for this since admins should not have to opt out of broken
behavior. Since this API did not previously expect to return
a 409 response, the "expected_errors" decorator is updated
and again, should not require a microversion per the
guidelines:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/microversions.html#when-a-microversion-is-not-needed

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/wsgi/test_services.py

NOTE(mriedem): This is due to the rc_fields move from
change Iea182341f9419cb514a044f76864d6bec60a3683 in Rocky.

Change-Id: I0bd63b655ad3d3d39af8d15c781ce0a45efc8e3a
Closes-Bug: #1763183
(cherry picked from commit 42f62f1ed2ad76829eb9d40a8b9646a523f6381f)

subject: Use correct policy when faking misplaced objects in probe test
messages: [{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-05-21 07:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 17:58:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-21 07:38:52.000000000', 'message': "Use correct policy when faking misplaced objects in probe test

Before, merge_objects() always used storage policy index of 0 when
inserting a fake misplaced object into a shard container. If the shard
broker had a different policy index then the misplaced object would
not show in listings causing test_misplaced_object_movement() to
fail. This test bug might be exposed by having policy index 0 be an EC
policy, since the probe test requires a replication policy and would
therefore choose a non-zero policy index.

The fix is simply to specify the shard's policy index when inserting
the fake object.

Change-Id: Iec3f8ec29950220bb1b2ead9abfdfb1a261517d6
"}]
commit_message:
Use correct policy when faking misplaced objects in probe test

Before, merge_objects() always used storage policy index of 0 when
inserting a fake misplaced object into a shard container. If the shard
broker had a different policy index then the misplaced object would
not show in listings causing test_misplaced_object_movement() to
fail. This test bug might be exposed by having policy index 0 be an EC
policy, since the probe test requires a replication policy and would
therefore choose a non-zero policy index.

The fix is simply to specify the shard's policy index when inserting
the fake object.

Change-Id: Iec3f8ec29950220bb1b2ead9abfdfb1a261517d6

subject: Fix-up signal handling
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 18:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-05-21 19:04:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

I'm not 100% sure this is strictly better in all cases.  It's possible I don't understand the race that's being described.  Maybe a unittest would demonstrate the failure and make it more obvious?

I trust Tim tho for sure!!!"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 20:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-05-21 20:13:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The signal-handler stuff was because doing anything complicated in a signal handler is a bad idea, and something as simple as "logger.info('dead now')" may involve locks, which involve pipe IO, which might involve switching greenthreads, which could result in some other greenthread that was happily doing its thing wind up running again, but in a signal-handler context.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-05-21 20:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

if the goal is to fix the race, maybe a better design such that the context is "sigterm recieved = True" and we just never let sighup overwrite that?

OTOH, timburke says killpg is already idempotent, so maybe it's fine if we do that everytime you send sigterm?

Sam says as long as it's not i/o we're ok on the deadlock front.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-21 18:21:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix-up signal handling

- Only allow SIGHUP to be handled once.
- Have SIGTERM perform the os.killpg() inside the signal handler to
  avoid a race condition where a SIGTERM followed quickly by a SIGHUP
  would never kill the child processes.

Change-Id: I7b7b2b3f637333e43b139d9b7ef7d22e249c2175
'}]
commit_message:
Fix-up signal handling

- Only allow SIGHUP to be handled once.
- Have SIGTERM perform the os.killpg() inside the signal handler to
  avoid a race condition where a SIGTERM followed quickly by a SIGHUP
  would never kill the child processes.

Change-Id: I7b7b2b3f637333e43b139d9b7ef7d22e249c2175

Oh yeah, *and* we're more graceful if the Ctrl-C happens to occur while we're down in strategy.new_worker_socks or strategy.register_worker_start or the like."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-05-21 19:08:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I think I sorta knew you could this on a conceptual level - but never considered that python must implement KeyboardInterrupt as a signal handler!  That's mad!"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 20:11:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-21 18:21:25.000000000', 'message': 'Handle SIGINT more like we do SIGHUP and SIGTERM

Saves us a try/except block, we've already got the signal handler -- may
as well use it!

Slight downside of changing the logging from "User quit" at NOTICE to
"SIGINT received" at error, though. *shrug*

Change-Id: I08c659b80d5b9982eb37205cb09b6ade19e00306
'}]
commit_message:
Handle SIGINT more like we do SIGHUP and SIGTERM

Saves us a try/except block, we've already got the signal handler -- may
as well use it!

Slight downside of changing the logging from "User quit" at NOTICE to
"SIGINT received" at error, though. *shrug*

Change-Id: I08c659b80d5b9982eb37205cb09b6ade19e00306

'}, {'created': '2018-03-06 23:50:40.000000000', 'message': "Configure nova to auto-calculate compute RPC upgrade levels

The openstack-ansible team found a regression in Queens when setting
the compute RPC upgrade_levels to 'auto' on a fresh install before any
computes had started up. The dependent change fixes the issue in nova
but for future proofing against this sort of issue again, we can set
the compute RPC upgrade levels in devstack to 'auto' for fresh installs
as well. Note that grenade already sets 'auto' for compute upgrade
levels, which is why we didn't catch this in grenade testing with the
compute RPC 5.0 version bump that caused the issue.

commit_message:
Configure nova to auto-calculate compute RPC upgrade levels

The openstack-ansible team found a regression in Queens when setting
the compute RPC upgrade_levels to 'auto' on a fresh install before any
computes had started up. The dependent change fixes the issue in nova
but for future proofing against this sort of issue again, we can set
the compute RPC upgrade levels in devstack to 'auto' for fresh installs
as well. Note that grenade already sets 'auto' for compute upgrade
levels, which is why we didn't catch this in grenade testing with the
compute RPC 5.0 version bump that caused the issue.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/549737/

Change-Id: I07f34dbc09b6108ba8f5b2a83a28c75eb42be495
Related-Bug: #1753443

commit_message:
Remove IRONIC_USE_RESOURCE_CLASSES check

Nova has dropped support for non-resource class
baremetal scheduling, so the IRONIC_USE_RESOURCE_CLASSES
flag is no longer useful and has been removed.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/565805/
Change-Id: Ib2e6c96409c98877f6a43b76f176c1420d2d415e

subject: SQUASH: fix-up signal handling
messages: [{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-11 20:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 18:52:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nProposed https://review.openstack.org/#/c/569837/ against master'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 20:19:24.000000000', 'message': 'SQUASH: fix-up signal handling

- Only allow SIGHUP to be handled once.
- Have SIGTERM perform the os.killpg() inside the signal handler to
  avoid a race condition where a SIGTERM followed quickly by a SIGHUP
  would never kill the child processes.

Change-Id: I7b7b2b3f637333e43b139d9b7ef7d22e249c2175
'}]
commit_message:
SQUASH: fix-up signal handling

- Only allow SIGHUP to be handled once.
- Have SIGTERM perform the os.killpg() inside the signal handler to
  avoid a race condition where a SIGTERM followed quickly by a SIGHUP
  would never kill the child processes.

Change-Id: I7b7b2b3f637333e43b139d9b7ef7d22e249c2175

messages:

Oh yeah, *and* we're more graceful if the Ctrl-C happens to occur while we're down in strategy.new_worker_socks or strategy.register_worker_start or the like."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-05-21 18:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Proposed https://review.openstack.org/#/c/569838/ against master'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 20:19:24.000000000', 'message': 'SQUASH: Handle SIGINT more like we do SIGHUP and SIGTERM

Saves us a try/except block, we've already got the signal handler -- may
as well use it!

Slight downside of changing the logging from "User quit" at NOTICE to
"SIGINT received" at error, though. *shrug*

Change-Id: I08c659b80d5b9982eb37205cb09b6ade19e00306
'}]
commit_message:
SQUASH: Handle SIGINT more like we do SIGHUP and SIGTERM

Saves us a try/except block, we've already got the signal handler -- may
as well use it!

Slight downside of changing the logging from "User quit" at NOTICE to
"SIGINT received" at error, though. *shrug*

Change-Id: I08c659b80d5b9982eb37205cb09b6ade19e00306

[{'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-16 02:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-16 03:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-16 05:05:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

What project is pulling this in where exactly is the bug?  The linked bug doesn't have much detail.  I don't think I'm against adding it, but we need more details as to why.  How can I reproduce the error?"}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-16 06:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for your comment. I also detail issue info in https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-requirements/+bug/1771479'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-16 13:32:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567458/6/tox.ini

Without Pygments in the test-requirements it will fail like the linked bug'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-16 15:37:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

ok, sounds like you need it, but I'm still not sure why.  What in particular is pulling pygments in?  (where is the import)?  Also, if you wish to add a new library to global-requirements.txt you'll need to answer the questions from the following link in the commit message.

https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/dependency-management.html#for-new-requirements"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-16 15:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@matthew It looks like doc8 is?

http://logs.openstack.org/58/567458/4/check/openstack-tox-pep8/73b32e7/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-05-14_09_45_56_535441 says:

D000 Cannot analyze code. Pygments package not found.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-16 15:52:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't see an import there though, where is it actually trying to import it?"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-16 15:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-17 02:25:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So The bottom line here, as I understand it, is that doc8 on the designate docs is currently ignoring all D000 errors and would like to stop ignoring them.

D000 is done via docutils/setuptools but it's an *optional* check with a hard error [1]

So for any project that wants to perform similar checks will also need Pygments available.

I don't think Pymnets qualifies as a linter so we'll need to add this properly and include it in {lower,upper}-constraints.txt

[1] http://repo.or.cz/docutils.git/blob/HEAD:/sandbox/gitpull/setuptools/docutils/utils/code_analyzer.py#l11"}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-17 02:31:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-17 02:32:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Looks godo to me.  Now that we understand why it's needed.

Keen observers will spot the 6 mins where I changed my mind ;P"}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-17 04:23:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

need to remove pygments from UC if it's in blacklist."}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-17 05:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-05-17 06:54:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-17 06:58:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-17 07:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Thanks Tony. I had missed update from gerrit, thus I had pushed same contents your PS.'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-05-17 08:09:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1770786

If you believe we've correctly identified the failure, feel free to leave a 'recheck' comment to run the tests again.
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/"}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2018-05-17 09:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-17 13:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-17 14:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2018-05-21 16:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

Is the library actively maintained?
Yes - https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/pygments-main

Is the library good code?
Yes - It is the defacto syntax highlighting code in Python

Is the library python 3 compatible?
Yes

Is the library license compatible?
Yes - BSD

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest / Fedora latest)?
Yes

Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in global-requirements.txt?
No

Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?
Yes - for doc8 checking where there is code snippets.
It is also a transient dependancy of sphinx - https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/master/setup.py#L21

Change-Id: I643c7632a02c87820c9c51f03fa34f0764384783
Close-bug: #1771479

commit_message:
Allow Pygments in openstack/requirements

Projects that want to enable a comprehensive doc8 check of code,
including D000, need Pygmnets to be installable.  It's an option library
used by docutils so we need to track it here.

While this isn't really a linter, neither is it really required at
runtime for the projects using it so it's added to the blacklist

Is the library actively maintained?
Yes - https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/pygments-main

Is the library good code?
Yes - It is the defacto syntax highlighting code in Python

Is the library python 3 compatible?
Yes

Is the library license compatible?
Yes - BSD

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest / Fedora latest)?
Yes

Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in global-requirements.txt?
No

Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?
Yes - for doc8 checking where there is code snippets.
It is also a transient dependancy of sphinx - https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/master/setup.py#L21

Change-Id: I643c7632a02c87820c9c51f03fa34f0764384783
Close-bug: #1771479

Replace any redhat/quickstart previous reference

Since we are now on the new repository, we want to use it as a reference
instead of the original one, "redhat-openstack/tripleo-quickstart-utils":
this commit replaces any reference with "openstack/tripleo-ha-utils".

Change-Id: Ibc1c62e498c2fc9b84d88e245df080cf8c9471cc

commit_message:
Deprecate tripleo::profile::base::docker(_registry)

These profiles are replaced by https://github.com/openstack/ansible-role-container-registry,
so we deprecate it now and will remove the code in the future.

Depends-On: Iee0e08cd48f173a39a6f3a1ea54b29e370d4f334
Change-Id: I9e2a475e4582deec383b92f368e9a834122f65bb

commit_message:
Fix idents in setting undercloud hostname

Because of wrong idents setting undercloud hostname in script
doesn't work. Fix idents in ansible task.

Change-Id: I1e34b8974ff98219f666e8864189c496ae8d0be6

commit_message:
Chain ansible messages in deployment progress

This change stores incoming config-deploy ansible messages in a List
Rendering of ansible messages is moved into separate component which
automatically scrolls to the bottom of the messages output

Implements: blueprint config-download-ui
Change-Id: I0262cfebfdf43e1f6d2282ae78b174a49492ab6b

This adds a dashboard for displaying prometheus specific metrics,
providing insight into the performance of prometheus as well as

Change-Id: I2c23c6fc9d0a00236cd38c63d29207e04a368f5f

commit_message:
Grafana: Add Prometheus dashboard

This adds a dashboard for displaying prometheus specific metrics,
providing insight into the performance of prometheus as well as
metrics related to time series, rule evaluations, scrape delays,
and query latency

Change-Id: I2c23c6fc9d0a00236cd38c63d29207e04a368f5f

[{'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-11-29 19:44:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-11-29 20:13:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This LGTM.

One thing that is worth discussing - but I don't know if this is the right forum - is how we migrate from the existing (default) policies where effectively any role on the project implies writer (and in most but not all cases the admin role implies system admin, per bug 968696) to this new, much improved, system. Maybe that's another spec though?"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-11-29 20:31:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This LGTM.
 > 
 > One thing that is worth discussing - but I don't know if this is
 > the right forum - is how we migrate from the existing (default)
 > policies where effectively any role on the project implies writer
 > (and in most but not all cases the admin role implies system admin,
 > per bug 968696) to this new, much improved, system. Maybe that's
 > another spec though?

Yeah - that's a good question. We talked about that a lot during the PTG. The best would could come up with is a compatibility shim in oslo.policy that knows how to handle both cases.

Before a deployment can truly switch over the new model, the operator needs to go through and do a who's who with the users (e.g. does this person need a role assignment on the system, or a project, in order to keep doing their job). Once everything is triaged and assigned correctly, the deployment should be able to run without the compatibility shim in oslo.policy."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-11-29 20:42:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-11-29 20:50:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2017-11-29 20:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-31 01:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Implied roles were designed to help out with defining roles.  

The way I have been thinking of them is in three tiers:

Bottom is the most fine grained roles:  
Middle is workflows that combiner multiple fine grained roles
Top is the User assigned roles.  These could even be Domain specific roles.

For the most fine grained, I think we start with read, create modify, delete on each resource.  There might be more fine grained ones that people want, but I don't think we can do that just yet.  

The work flows in the middle are like "Create new VM"  "set up network" and the like

The top level roles are project_admin, member, auditor, cleanup.   Cleanup is for automated processes that just delete resources when their time is up.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-31 17:02:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(3 comments)

Some good bike shedding material inline, but I do like what this spec is proposing and think it would be a good thing to move forward with.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-04-02 15:09:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-04-02 15:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-04-02 15:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-04-02 15:13:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

@adam -- the upstream team discussed using implied roles to do this but opted out because of the associated complexity (as outlined in the spec). Our primary objective is to get some agreement on what the initial set of default roles should be, get them into some policy files (for easy testing), and then iterate and expand across OS based on the results. These likely won't be the final solution and the policy-file approach is simply a stepping stone until we can move things into code. Between other, relevant items on the teams agenda over the past many cycles and the bike shedding on this topic it really is time to just get something in that we, and our operators, can test and iterate on as a team."}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-04-02 15:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-04-03 19:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Huge -1 on using "operator" as the member-equivalent role.

For what it's worth, AWS uses "read" and "write" to distinguish these access levels separate from the "permissions management" (admin) level: https://aws.amazon.com/iam/details/manage-permissions/

I also don't think member is the worst name for this. It connotes association without implying administrator-level access.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-04-03 19:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Oh, so maybe reader/writer may have more general acceptance than I was aware of. I guess in that case, as long as the roles are equivalent in end user expectations, we probably should go with the originally proposed names.

Thanks for pointing that out!

FWIW, I'm fine with member too. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-04-04 15:18:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-04-10 11:27:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

(2 comments)

Looks good overall. 

Does keystone have a recommended way of communicating changes to the default policy? Release notes? Some way to issue deprecation warnings before switching? More concretely, Ironic has an 'observer' role which should change to 'auditor' if we implement the changes here. What's the best way to do that without breaking someone's deployment?"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-04-10 14:50:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Looks good overall.
 > 
 > Does keystone have a recommended way of communicating changes to
 > the default policy? Release notes? Some way to issue deprecation
 > warnings before switching? More concretely, Ironic has an
 > 'observer' role which should change to 'auditor' if we implement
 > the changes here. What's the best way to do that without breaking
 > someone's deployment?

That's a good question. The oslo.policy library does have support for deprecating policy rules [0] and it tries to do some aliasing based on the situation when loading the rules during enforcement [1].

Ironic could use the DeprecatedRuleDefault class in oslo.policy to change check strings away from the "observer" role to the "auditor" role [2]. We do log things for operators, so if they decide they want to keep the "observer" naming, they totally can. All they have to do is copy paste the policy and maintain it as an override. Otherwise, if an operator wants to move to "auditor" instead, they will have that role available to them after they run keystone-manage db_sync during a Rocky upgrade. Once the operator assigns all current observers the "auditor" role, they should be able to do the same things as before, just with the default policy. Then the operator can remove the "observer" role. Obviously a lot of moving pieces, especially if someone is using custom policy.

Hopefully that helps clear things up.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.policy/latest/reference/api/oslo_policy.policy.html#oslo_policy.policy.DeprecatedRule
[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/master/oslo_policy/policy.py#L565-L627
[2] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/common/policy.py#L114-L116'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-04-10 16:00:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-04-10 16:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(2 comments)

> That's a good question. The oslo.policy library does have support
 > for deprecating policy rules [0] and it tries to do some aliasing
 > based on the situation when loading the rules during enforcement
 > [1].
 > 
 > Ironic could use the DeprecatedRuleDefault class in oslo.policy to
 > change check strings away from the "observer" role to the "auditor"
 > role [2]. 

Sounds like this should work. This was my main question, thanks for answering that!

 > We do log things for operators, so if they decide they
 > want to keep the "observer" naming, they totally can. All they have
 > to do is copy paste the policy and maintain it as an override.

Yep, makes sense. We'll have to make sure we have release notes for any new rules, as the operator will need to add an override for anything new that allows "auditor" permission. And if they miss one, hopefully they don't give the auditor role out for something else and suddenly give some unintended access. :)

 > Otherwise, if an operator wants to move to "auditor" instead, they
 > will have that role available to them after they run
 > keystone-manage db_sync during a Rocky upgrade. Once the operator
 > assigns all current observers the "auditor" role, they should be
 > able to do the same things as before, just with the default policy.
 > Then the operator can remove the "observer" role. Obviously a lot
 > of moving pieces, especially if someone is using custom policy.

*thumbs up* that's what I figured. Thanks Lance.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-04-10 20:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-04-10 21:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Close, but really need to drop the user examples, as that will confuse things due to Domain scoping.  I would suggest you put in an explicit disclaimer about Domain scoping, as I suggested last revision; it will keep people from panicking.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-04-16 14:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-04-16 15:05:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1

Nicely done.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-04-16 20:29:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1

This is awesome, I'm happy with this.

Thanks for keeping this going, Harry."}, {'account_id': 8866, 'date': '2018-05-03 12:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1

Well done!'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-05-04 14:15:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-05-04 14:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-05-04 15:44:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1

Much more clear now.  Looks good.
I still think we have an unanswered standardization around "global-observer" roles and service specific roles, but this does not limit the ability to have those, so +1 from me.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-05-04 19:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Context: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-05-04.log.html#t2018-05-04T14:23:09'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-05-21 17:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 19:44:35.000000000', 'message': 'Define a set of basic default roles

With the recent work to keystone and oslo.policy, we should be able to
offer tooling to project development teams so they can start evolving
their policies. Before we start changing things, we should come to
consensus on a set of defaults we should offer out of the box.

Moving towards a set of known defaults will make maintenance for
operators much easier. It will also build the foundation for a more
robust RBAC system that is better at modeling complex
organization, ultimately being more useful in the real-world.

Change-Id: I643a2e668599ae77eb615d1b292a59e5066dcbb5

organization, ultimately being more useful in the real-world.

Co-authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbagstad@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jamie Lennox <jamielennox@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I643a2e668599ae77eb615d1b292a59e5066dcbb5

commit_message:
Define a set of basic default roles

With the recent work to keystone and oslo.policy, we should be able to
offer tooling to project development teams so they can start evolving
their policies. Before we start changing things, we should come to
consensus on a set of defaults we should offer out of the box.

Moving towards a set of known defaults will make maintenance for
operators much easier. It will also build the foundation for a more
robust RBAC system that is better at modeling complex
organization, ultimately being more useful in the real-world.

Co-authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbagstad@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jamie Lennox <jamielennox@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I643a2e668599ae77eb615d1b292a59e5066dcbb5

Pike branch has failing tests due to a few deprecated policies in Cinder and Neutron. We will need to discuss how to fallback to a previously used policy in order to support previous branches in Patrole.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-03-22 05:22:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

yea these have been renamed during policy-in-code in backward incompatible way. 

What we can do, we keep testing with new policy on master what we do currently and skip renamed policy test for stable branches with feature flag.

Even projects agree to maintain  policy in compatible way we cannot guarantee to break patrole test like this till we gate patrole job pon projects side. 
So let's go with below plan:

1. patrole test master with all the latest policy what projects has.
2. skip test for renamed policy on stable branch
3. start gating patrole on projects side which means we get agreement from project side not to change policy in backward incompatible way"}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2018-03-22 16:26:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Make patrole-member job run for queens and pike branches

This makes patrole-member job run for queens and pike branches.
Arguably it is also important to do this for admin role, but
for now we will verify stability with Member role before extending
to admin role.

Change-Id: I76c4a9b8737bf94f230ab141def652b054120f3b

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Thanks for quick proposal.

Thanks for the feedback. I considered doing individual feature flags but didn't like it from an implementation POV (it's just not elegant).

But what you say is true: This patch allows people to skip tests whenever they want which is bad. I think doing traditional feature flag, one per policy (I count 6 failures right now in [0]) plus @testtools.skipUnless will work without letting people skip tests whenever they want.

I will make suggested changes in next PS by adding on feature flag for each of the 6 backwards-incompatible policies.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-25 04:34:35.000000000', 'message': "feature flag: Backwards incompatible policies

A new configuration option,
``[patrole].backwards_incompatible_rules``, has been added which
allows for the possibility of enumerating policy names that are
not supported in N-1 and earlier OpenStack releases because they
were renamed or removed in a backwards-incompatible way by a
service in a later release.

This option is a ListOpt which shall contain the backwards-
incompatible policy names not supported in N-1, N-2 or
earlier.

The option is checked in rbac_rule_validation where it can
detect the rule passed in to the rbac_rule_validation.action
decorator and compare it against the list of backwards-
incompatible policies, the tests for which should be skipped.

The motivation behind this feature flag is [0] which adds
Pike/Queens gating to Patrole. However, in Queens, Neutron
and Cinder renamed or removed a few policies in a backwards-
incompatible way. These policies can be reviewed here: [1].

This PS requires a follow up in devstack's lib/tempest
because Patrole, being a branchless project and hosting the
Patrole devstack plugin itself, must fall back to Tempest's
devstack script to list out the backwards-incompatible
policies in Pike. This will include (for now) 5-7 policy
names.

A documentation update will also come in a follow up with
information on this feature flag, its motivation, and
how to use it.

[0] I76c4a9b8737bf94f230ab141def652b054120f3b
[1] e.g. http://logs.openstack.org/51/547851/4/check/patrole-member-pike/139c534/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-22_21_46_08_392229

Change-Id: Ia0d9847908a8e723446c16465d68cd7f622c04cc

commit_message:
feature flag: Policy feature enabled config group

A new configuration group ``[policy_feature_enabled]`` has been added to
Patrole which will be responsible for collecting the feature flags to be
used for newly introduced policies or policies that were changed in a
backwards-incompatible way.

    * create_port_fixed_ips_ip_address_policy (Neutron)
    * update_port_fixed_ips_ip_address_policy (Neutron)
    * limits_extension_used_limits_policy (Cinder)
    * volume_extension_volume_actions_attach_policy (Cinder)
    * volume_extension_volume_actions_reserve_policy (Cinder)
    * volume_extension_volume_actions_unreserve_policy (Cinder)

These feature flags will be supported until Pike release cycle
is EOL.

The motivation behind these feature flags is [0] which adds
Pike/Queens gating to Patrole. However, in Queens, Neutron
and Cinder renamed or removed a few policies in a backwards-
incompatible way. These policies can be reviewed here: [1].

This PS requires another PS [2] in devstack's lib/tempest
because Patrole, being a branchless project and hosting the
Patrole devstack plugin itself, must fall back to Tempest's
devstack script to list out the backwards-incompatible
policies in Pike.

A documentation update will also come in a follow up with
information on these feature flags.

[0] I76c4a9b8737bf94f230ab141def652b054120f3b
[1] e.g. http://logs.openstack.org/51/547851/4/check/patrole-member-pike/139c534/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-22_21_46_08_392229
[2] I00bdeff9474c54d38b6d6844a041b305bec01ad8

Change-Id: Ia0d9847908a8e723446c16465d68cd7f622c04cc

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-17 14:59:18.000000000', 'message': "Force GDPR compliance of containers logs

After purge_after_days, defaults to a 14, forcibly remove
any rotated and compressed logs of containerized services
in /var/log/containers. This overrides any related
containerized logrotate configuration used for
containerized services.

Allow to alter rotation interval for log files managed
via containerized logrotate. Defaults to 'daily'
and rotate 14 (days).

Additionally, to enforce GDPR compliance of log files
in /var/log/containers, put them under logrotate management
(minsize 1) and always compress. Prohibit the size option
as it does not honor time-based contstraints required by
GDPR. Forcibly remove all files but those rotated and
compressed logs, via the postscript section.

Partial-bug: #1771543

Change-Id: Id8e4717a5ecda53bc9cd39f1c2efaa80b56bd45e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Additionally, to enforce GDPR compliance of log files

Change-Id: Id8e4717a5ecda53bc9cd39f1c2efaa80b56bd45e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-05-18 08:08:35.000000000', 'message': "Force GDPR compliance of containers logs

After purge_after_days, defaults to a 14, forcibly remove
any rotated and compressed logs of containerized services
in /var/log/containers. This overrides any related
containerized logrotate configuration used for
containerized services.

Allow to alter rotation interval for log files managed
via containerized logrotate. Defaults to 'daily'
and rotate 14 (days).

Use sharedscripts to clean up files in the postrotate
script only once.

Additionally, to enforce GDPR compliance of log files
in /var/log/containers, put them under logrotate management
(minsize 1) and always compress. Prohibit the size option
as it does not honor time-based contstraints required by
GDPR. Forcibly remove all files but those rotated and
compressed logs, via the postscript section.

Partial-bug: #1771543

any rotated and compressed logs of containerized services
in /var/log/containers. This overrides any related
containerized logrotate configuration used for
containerized services.

Allow to alter rotation interval for log files managed
via containerized logrotate. Defaults to 'daily'
and rotate 14 (days).

Use sharedscripts to clean up files in the postrotate
script only once.

Additionally, to enforce GDPR compliance of log files
in /var/log/containers, put them under logrotate management
(minsize 1) and always compress. Prohibit the size option

commit_message:
Force GDPR compliance of containers logs

After purge_after_days, defaults to a 14, forcibly remove
any rotated and compressed logs of containerized services
in /var/log/containers. This overrides any related
containerized logrotate configuration used for
containerized services.

Allow to alter rotation interval for log files managed
via containerized logrotate. Defaults to 'daily'
and rotate 14 (days).

Use sharedscripts to clean up files in the postrotate
script only once.

Additionally, to enforce GDPR compliance of log files
in /var/log/containers, put them under logrotate management
(minsize 1) and always compress. Prohibit the size option
as it does not honor time-based contstraints required by
GDPR. Forcibly remove all files but those rotated and
compressed logs, via the postscript section.

Partial-bug: #1771543

Change-Id: Id8e4717a5ecda53bc9cd39f1c2efaa80b56bd45e
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove APIs for managing security groups

These APIs are proxy to Neutron API calls. Users can achieve the
equivalent functionality by directly calling the Neutron APIs.
In particular, these APIs are removed after microversion 1.15
* POST /containers/<ident>/add_security_group
* POST /containers/<ident>/remove_security_group

Change-Id: Ifd39948fec7e94b6e78298b3a6ccbed947f7ce61
Implements: blueprint rework-security-group-api

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 18:03:38.000000000', 'message': 'Add vault password and config path to env vars

This change sets the KAYOBE_VAULT_PASSWORD environment variable when a
vault password file is specified via --vault-password-file. This allows
the kayobe playbooks to use the password to encrypt and decrypt the
kolla ansible passwords.yml file.

We also set the KAYOBE_CONFIG_PATH environment variable, to ensure that
kayobe playbooks set the {{ kayobe_config_path }} variable correctly
when the config path is specified via --config-path.

Change-Id: Id61527ff5e76cac3a485746a1c2898f03ed1bce6
Story: 2001664
Task: 6699
'}]
commit_message:
Add vault password and config path to env vars

This change sets the KAYOBE_VAULT_PASSWORD environment variable when a
vault password file is specified via --vault-password-file. This allows
the kayobe playbooks to use the password to encrypt and decrypt the
kolla ansible passwords.yml file.

We also set the KAYOBE_CONFIG_PATH environment variable, to ensure that
kayobe playbooks set the {{ kayobe_config_path }} variable correctly
when the config path is specified via --config-path.

Change-Id: Id61527ff5e76cac3a485746a1c2898f03ed1bce6
Story: 2001664
Task: 6699

subject: Fix Contract on Project property, extra.
messages: [{'account_id': 26101, 'date': '2018-04-10 20:52:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2018-04-11 13:36:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2018-04-12 10:58:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13671, 'date': '2018-05-21 14:05:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/queens as commit 254ac9c57d71c5d0b3ba1cec3a3fdd61564c9eb1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 20:52:21.000000000', 'message': "Fix Contract on Project property, extra.

The current contract for this property (in Project.yaml) is:

      extra:
        Contract:
          $.string().notNull(): $.string()

Deploying my Murano application, the code attempts to populate this
property with:

     u'tags': []

and gets this error:

    ContractViolationException: [io.murano.Project.extra['tags']] Value [] violates string() contract

My fix is:

        extra:
        Contract:
          $.string().notNull(): $

This allows the 2nd value of the pair to be any scalar or data structure.  A string
or a list of strings is acceptable now.

Change-Id: I1b0438ad451db2b7a89a9fb65dc948b52ceb2f3f
Co-Authored-By: Devjani Ray <devjani.ray@oracle.com>
Closes-Bug: 1762821
"}]
commit_message:
Fix Contract on Project property, extra.

The current contract for this property (in Project.yaml) is:

      extra:
        Contract:
          $.string().notNull(): $.string()

Deploying my Murano application, the code attempts to populate this
property with:

     u'tags': []

and gets this error:

    ContractViolationException: [io.murano.Project.extra['tags']] Value [] violates string() contract

My fix is:

        extra:
        Contract:
          $.string().notNull(): $

This allows the 2nd value of the pair to be any scalar or data structure.  A string
or a list of strings is acceptable now.

Change-Id: I1b0438ad451db2b7a89a9fb65dc948b52ceb2f3f
Co-Authored-By: Devjani Ray <devjani.ray@oracle.com>
Closes-Bug: 1762821

Can you share what the output looks like?"}, {'account_id': 11085, 'date': '2018-04-30 15:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11085, 'date': '2018-04-30 15:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think this change strikes a better balance.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-05-08 13:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

So I found the output in CI. This is what it looks like with this patch... 

https://logs.rdoproject.org/85/564585/4/openstack-check/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset035-master/Z656de0b93df44901b96f310617af6ee2/undercloud/home/jenkins/overcloud_prep_images.log.txt.gz#_2018-04-30_20_49_31

and this is what it looks like without the patch:

https://logs.rdoproject.org/50/566050/9/openstack-check/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset035-master/Z82fb0b119c364f629597141a9022a161/undercloud/home/jenkins/overcloud_prep_images.log.txt.gz#_2018-05-08_10_15_58

The blank lines have been removed - that is good! (I am not sure where they come from, I suspect the workflow is sending empty messages but they are being printed regardless. Probably one reason why we shouldn't set the message to an empty string in workflows but that is another matter!).

Otherwise I think some useful lines have been removed. For example I don't see this summary message anymore... "4 node(s) successfully moved to the "manageable" state."'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-05-08 14:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Improve output when registering nodes.

Currently when registering nodes with the openstack unified interface
there is to much information dumped to the command line. This change
looks to correct that by adding debug log statements to the points where
the message bus was being printed to the command line.

Closes-Bug: 1710685
Change-Id: Ie45900df4d50e2c3b1d0a54bd2f9e5561da5101b

commit_message:
Add .deployment.v1.deploy_on_servers to ffwd-upgrade prepare

Before we update the heat stack for the ffwd-upgrade prepare we
can use this to run any required commands on the overcloud.

The current use case is removal of the
/usr/libexec/os-apply-config/templates/etc/os-net-config/config.json
Otherwise after the upgrade prepare is executed, overcloud nodes
will have empty config.json for os-net-config (also discussed [0])

The current implementation of .deployment.v1.deploy_on_servers assumes
all servers are managed by nova. This is OK for N..Q ffu but we will
need to revisit in future, see [1] for more info.

[0]: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1561255
[1]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1770356
Related-Bug: 1758161
Related:
    tripleo-common Ic138c4925c5c96d1cf718af7ae59bcf5f0ba96dc
Change-Id: I77fdc9deab97c785725f09b8529c512950753f86

In the following APIs, the 'volume_id' parameters are
'path' parameters. So fix them.

- GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}
- DELETE /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}

In addition, the descriptions of the parameters are amended.

Change-Id: Iab93acde31639b1471c83b06fb1a77474bb52c48
Closes-Bug: #1770560
"}]
commit_message:
api-ref: Fix parameters for os-volume-attachments.inc

In the following APIs, the 'volume_id' parameters are
'path' parameters. So fix them.

- GET /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}
- DELETE /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}

In addition, the descriptions of the parameters are amended.

Change-Id: Iab93acde31639b1471c83b06fb1a77474bb52c48
Closes-Bug: #1770560

subject: Pin pip < 10 in the amphora image
messages: [{'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-04-19 22:17:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/pike.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-05-18 16:56:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-05-18 17:52:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-05-21 12:14:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-19 22:17:12.000000000', 'message': 'Pin pip < 10 in the amphora image

pip 10 fails when installing the amphora-agent due to a package conflict
in oslo.config PyYAML and the python3-yaml installed in the base images.
We cannot backport the venv fix from master as the stable branch uses
the ubuntu element which does not have enough disk space to install with the
venv.
So to make a minimal fix for the stable branches we are going to pin pip
in the amphora image.

(cherry picked from commit 9e1ced71e1e270777b15adbcde8de03577375964)

Change-Id: Ia74f63888b7e4fbcf5392a7d3ec392bddb57f9e7
'}]
commit_message:
Pin pip < 10 in the amphora image

pip 10 fails when installing the amphora-agent due to a package conflict
in oslo.config PyYAML and the python3-yaml installed in the base images.
We cannot backport the venv fix from master as the stable branch uses
the ubuntu element which does not have enough disk space to install with the
venv.
So to make a minimal fix for the stable branches we are going to pin pip
in the amphora image.

(cherry picked from commit 9e1ced71e1e270777b15adbcde8de03577375964)

Change-Id: Ia74f63888b7e4fbcf5392a7d3ec392bddb57f9e7

Enhance completion message when upgrading non controller nodes

This adds a better completion message when upgrading a non
controller node.

Closes-Bug: 1703792

subject: Support running external playbooks
messages:
[{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-11 16:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-12 11:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-12 12:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-18 15:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-01 18:28:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-03 09:48:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

This is currently not working as expected with ansible 2.4+ due to a change in ansible behaviour. Group variables are now always taken from a group_vars directory relative to the current playbook, not the root playbook (which was the behaviour in ansible 2.3).

Given that the main function of include_playbook.yml is to support kayobe's playbook group variables, this patch needs some work."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-21 12:49:33.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This approach won't work in ansible 2.4+, since playbook group variables are pulled in relative to the current playbook rather than the top level playbook."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-11 16:13:17.000000000', 'message': 'Support running external playbooks

Adds support for running playbooks outside of the kayobe source code
repository, whilst retaining the use of playbook group variables defined
in ansible/group_vars.

This forms the basis for supporting customisable extensions to the
standard workflows.

Change-Id: Iaa66516d667f7e24a0684288dd3f67cd84fc5323
Story: 2001663
Task: 12577

commit_message:
Support running external playbooks

Adds support for running playbooks outside of the kayobe source code
repository, whilst retaining the use of playbook group variables defined
in ansible/group_vars.

This forms the basis for supporting customisable extensions to the
standard workflows.

Change-Id: Iaa66516d667f7e24a0684288dd3f67cd84fc5323
Story: 2001663
Task: 12577

subprocess module

[{'created': '2018-05-11 18:33:29.000000000', 'message': "Handle port's 'port_security_enabled' flag when adding ACLs

When a port's security groups are cleared and 'port_security_enabled'
flag is True, it is expected that all the traffic to/from the port is dropped.
But this is not the case. So this patch fixes this issue. 'port_security_enabled'
flag is checked before adding the port's ACLs.

So the new (and correct) behaviour with this patch is
 - No security groups and port security enabled -> Drop all the traffic
 - No security groups and port security disabled -> Allow all the traffic

Change-Id: I5265da4c21e58672db9858555625c8e2c5350316
Closes-bug: #1770723

commit_message:
Handle port's 'port_security_enabled' flag when adding ACLs

When a port's security groups are cleared and 'port_security_enabled'
flag is True, it is expected that all the traffic to/from the port is dropped.
But this is not the case. So this patch fixes this issue. 'port_security_enabled'
flag is checked before adding the port's ACLs.

So the new (and correct) behaviour with this patch is
 - No security groups and port security enabled -> Drop all the traffic
 - No security groups and port security disabled -> Allow all the traffic

Change-Id: I5265da4c21e58672db9858555625c8e2c5350316
Closes-bug: #1770723

commit_message:
Don't allow nested or stacks in FAILED state to be migrated

Stack and its nested stacks should be in *_COMPLETE state for
it to be migrated. Also, we should not allow migration of a
nested stack.

This also changes stack_get_all_by_owner_id() to not select the
backup stacks. This seems to be used only in convergence code
path and migrate_convergence_1().

Change-Id: Icd54465d0c593557a12d853ddee4ee8ce6483499
Closes-Bug: #1767962
Story: #1767962
Task: #17363

[{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-12 17:31:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-12 17:32:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 18368, 'date': '2018-04-17 08:42:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

bootstrap user use same ssh key as ansible user ? If we want to use an other key for bootstrap user ?'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-17 08:52:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> bootstrap user use same ssh key as ansible user ? If we want to use
 > an other key for bootstrap user ?

The bootstrap user uses the same key, yes. It will use ansible's normal logic for authentication - ansible_ssh_private_key_file, ansible_ssh_pass, keys in ~/.ssh/, etc.

What would the use case be for using a different SSH key for the bootstrap user? You would still need to ensure that the operator has access to the private key when doing the initial bootstrap? Or would you add it to kayobe-config?"}, {'account_id': 18368, 'date': '2018-04-27 13:19:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 18368, 'date': '2018-04-27 13:22:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > normal logic for authentication - ansible_ssh_private_key_file,
 > ansible_ssh_pass, keys in ~/.ssh/, etc.
 > 
 > What would the use case be for using a different SSH key for the
 > bootstrap user? You would still need to ensure that the operator
 > has access to the private key when doing the initial bootstrap? Or
 > would you add it to kayobe-config?

The boostrap key is added by bifrost or by operator (if we use static inventory). Somtimes the operator who install OS is not the same as the operator who deploy openstack."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-27 13:43:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > > What would the use case be for using a different SSH key for the
 > > bootstrap user? You would still need to ensure that the operator
 > > has access to the private key when doing the initial bootstrap?
 > Or
 > > would you add it to kayobe-config?
 > 
 > The boostrap key is added by bifrost or by operator (if we use
 > static inventory). Somtimes the operator who install OS is not the
 > same as the operator who deploy openstack.

The bootstrapper (human or automated) needs to provide access to the deployer. In the human case, I'd expect that they would provide an account for you with your SSH key authorised, right? The automated case here is similar."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-04 15:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-12 17:31:29.000000000', 'message': "Make kayobe ansible user bootstrap optional

The bootstrap user may be used to create the kayobe user account and configure
passwordless sudo. We can't assume that the bootstrap user account will exist
after the initial bootstrapping, or that the current operator's key is
authorised for the bootstrap user. We therefore attempt to access the kayobe
user account via SSH, and only perform the bootstrap process if the account is
inaccessible.

This change also adds some tasks to verify that the kayobe ansible user is
accessible and has passwordless sudo configured.

Change-Id: Ibdab0053caa2db71df2fd03cc8a598ae5aac73c9
Story: 2001659
Task: 6692

commit_message:
Make kayobe ansible user bootstrap optional

The bootstrap user may be used to create the kayobe user account and
configure passwordless sudo. We can't assume that the bootstrap user
account will exist after the initial bootstrapping, or that the current
operator's key is authorised for the bootstrap user. We therefore
attempt to access the kayobe user account via SSH, and only perform the
bootstrap process if the account is inaccessible.

This change also adds some tasks to verify that the kayobe ansible user
is accessible and has passwordless sudo configured.

Change-Id: Ibdab0053caa2db71df2fd03cc8a598ae5aac73c9
Story: 2001659
Task: 6692

since the boot_file may missing for user, could you please add a check to ensure it exists?'}, {'account_id': 26598, 'date': '2018-03-07 01:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> since the boot_file may missing for user, could you please add a
 > check to ensure it exists?

Hi, Yuan
Thanks for the review.
There is default value "pxelinux.0", which set in ironic-dnsmasq.conf.j2 before, only considering x86.
Now the default value is moved to ansible/roles/ironic/defaults/main.yml, for back compatibility.
In the mean time, add option in globals.yml for configure.
So I think the prechecks may not needed.
What do you think.'}, {'account_id': 24574, 'date': '2018-03-07 02:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-03-07 09:29:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> since the boot_file may missing for user, could you please add a
 > check to ensure it exists?

The bootfile referenced must exist in the ironic_pxe container, so I don't think it makes sense to check in prechecks as the container may not exist."}, {'account_id': 22165, 'date': '2018-03-07 09:39:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > since the boot_file may missing for user, could you please add a
 > > check to ensure it exists?
 > 
 > The bootfile referenced must exist in the ironic_pxe container, so
 > I don't think it makes sense to check in prechecks as the container
 > may not exist.

I see, thanks for explaination."}, {'account_id': 26598, 'date': '2018-05-18 08:29:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-18 08:38:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Adding ironic_dnsmasq_boot_file parameter to globals.yml

By now, ironic-dnsmasq has default bootfile pxelinux.0,
which is correct only for x86.
Adding ironic_dnsmasq_boot_file parameter to globals.yml
to make it configuable.
For example: /etc/kolla/globals.yml
ironic_dnsmasq_boot_file: "debian-installer/arm64/bootnetaa64.efi"

Change-Id: I6eb57702d4dad549ef8c999c1c82e577f316d8d6

commit_message:
Support deploying the Monasca API

Deploys the Monasca API with mod_wsgi + Apache.

Co-Authored-By: Mark Goddard <mark@stackhpc.com>

subject: Retry decorator fix for autoscale delete
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-21 10:56:42.000000000', 'message': "Retry decorator fix for autoscale delete

deallocate-network-retry

retry fix for VM going to ERROR state during auto-scale delete instance

Delete issued to building server leaves the instance in error state due to
not able to deallocate network error.During auto-scale delete, some of
the machines go into ERROR state rather than being deleted.This happens
once in a while during deletion of the instances at scale.Log line for
the failure is 'Setting instance vm_state to ERROR',
Failure in do_terminate_instance.

Change-Id: Ie29f8a92749ef96ce6c7b8c045d7986fe8036fe5
"}]
commit_message:
Retry decorator fix for autoscale delete

deallocate-network-retry

retry fix for VM going to ERROR state during auto-scale delete instance

Delete issued to building server leaves the instance in error state due to
not able to deallocate network error.During auto-scale delete, some of
the machines go into ERROR state rather than being deleted.This happens
once in a while during deletion of the instances at scale.Log line for
the failure is 'Setting instance vm_state to ERROR',
Failure in do_terminate_instance.

Change-Id: Ie29f8a92749ef96ce6c7b8c045d7986fe8036fe5

commit_message:
Validate that there should not be XFS volumes with ftype=0

If  we have XFS partitions formatted with ftype=0,
the upgrades will fail because ftype=0 is incompatible
with the docker overlayfs driver.

Related-Bug: 1765121
Change-Id: I895fc83d148523c283664080b7b1bf75d53d9edb
(cherry picked from commit a5e63ee72531c85ee527ce721022fffce3cfcf75)
(cherry picked from commit d54ae2d1e21245f7033107e1bae327621f54f82f)

commit_message:
Enable logging for tempest container

* In order to make sure tempest container is available in CI,
  It adds the logging for the same in /var/log/containers/tempest.

Change-Id: I3d526b374b6233bad69f5c6be12036b3ede37028

commit_message:
undercloud/upgrade: suggest backup before upgrade

Suggest to perform a backup before the undercloud upgrade and validate
that the restore works fine. It's to make sure our operators understand
this procedure is critical.
We'll also add some warning in tripleoclient so our operators are asked
to do a backup before proceeding to the upgrade.

Also removing the note about the fact any package can be upgraded. This
note is not useful as we're moving to containers anyway.

Change-Id: I1f076105a47b70d11311a8c950e0fe5760d6fd5f

commit_message:
Make instance HA uninstallation idempotent

This commit pairs with the one related to the pre checks [1] and make
the instance HA uninstallation idempotent, so that it will be possible
to run even if something was interrupted before.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567892/

Change-Id: I82c8bd4a41bce267fdad21c259c197e3edfe7497

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-18 11:35:46.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure files never bind-mounted as directories

Docker volumes create missing files as directories.
This highly likely breaks deployments in unexpected ways.

Make the common host prep tasks of containerized services
ensuring files will be bind-mounted as files and not as
directories.

Related bz: 1579409

Change-Id: Ib32c508cd4a193866f1ec24011587d07c15a2658
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure files never bind-mounted as directories

Docker volumes create missing files as directories.
This highly likely breaks deployments in unexpected ways.

Make the common host prep tasks of containerized services
ensuring files will be bind-mounted as files and not as
directories.

Related bz: 1579409

Change-Id: Ib32c508cd4a193866f1ec24011587d07c15a2658
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install

Install the dependencies explicitly in requirements instead of using
tox_install which does not work well with OpenStack CI.

Adapt tox.ini for this.

This commit includes the following unrelated change to pass
the gate.
----------------------------------------
gate_hook: Remove neutron repo from the list of tempest plugins

The code has been moved to neutron-tempest-plugins.

Closes-Bug: #1769904
Change-Id: I1213f4c9947248ae61b9954fec22f77fc6bb5d2d
----------------------------------------

Co-Authored-By: YAMAMOTO Takashi <yamamoto@midokura.com>
Change-Id: Iff427bbf9b659076e3bfecdd5e0bff9553db9dec

(2 comments)

Thanks for the reviews!

Personally, I don't like that the current code is changing the behavior of the routers for a flakey message bus.  The message bus has options to become more resilient, and we need a way to reflect that a router is dead because the agents hosting it are not alive.

If I have a max HA of 3 for routers and 10 network nodes...I need to be able to identify which routers are down when a handful of network nodes go down.  The current code doesn't support that, and I believe its intention is to do so.

But I very much recognize that I do not understand everything that was going on in the review with 411784.  I thought it was just due to a flaky message bus, but if it is more severe than that, let me know.  Maybe there is a good middle ground where both scenarios can be supported?"}, {'account_id': 8190, 'date': '2017-04-21 16:41:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

[{'created': '2017-04-21 12:06:23.000000000', 'message': 'Router should flip to standby if all L3 nodes down

A HA router should always be active unless all of the agents hosting
that router go down.  In that event, the router should switch to
standby.  This behavior changed with review:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/411784

That review seemed to be accounting for a flakey message bus.  This
change should account for that, but also revert to the original behavior
of the router state only changing when its backing agent hosts are down.

Change-Id: I89c3b2546382624f175f8de4de621c3e53adf527
Closes-Bug: 1682145

commit_message:
Router should flip to standby if all L3 nodes down

A HA router should always be active unless all of the agents hosting
that router go down.  In that event, the router should switch to
standby.  This behavior changed with review:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/411784

That review seemed to be accounting for a flakey message bus.  This
change should account for that, but also revert to the original behavior
of the router state only changing when its backing agent hosts are down.

Change-Id: I89c3b2546382624f175f8de4de621c3e53adf527
Closes-Bug: 1682145

commit_message:
Add Neutron L3 agent failover check during upgrade

This change adds suppport for validating that a router created on
the overcloud before upgrade remains active on the same node between
the various steps of the upgrade process and does not failover.

Change-Id: I1273367fb07bda5cdacb538081a87f9d3e5ece3c
(cherry picked from commit 71aaf58e6f263321c6119bcb2ae9f6f93176941d)
(cherry picked from commit aa0a0983b58007faa6264e08acb641f77ea5f6a3)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-04 11:14:02.000000000', 'message': 'Separate create scripts tasks by host.

The upgrade/update tasks in tripleo-upgrade started
with a create-scripts book, which generated most of
the scripts from the templates. However, this book
mixed the creation of scripts needed for the overcloud
as well as for the undercloud. This becomes an issue
when we want to perform only an undercloud upgrade, as
we are running tasks intended to the overcloud and it
might not even exist.
This patch divides the script creation tasks used for
the undercloud from the ones used for the overcloud.

Change-Id: I35dfbe50d12b65a8d14f62410adea551e7584912
Closes-Bug: #1769107

commit_message:
Separate scripts creation tasks for under/overcloud.

The upgrade/update tasks in tripleo-upgrade started
with a create-scripts book, which generated most of
the scripts from the templates. However, this book
mixed the creation of scripts needed for the overcloud
as well as for the undercloud. This becomes an issue
when we want to perform only an undercloud upgrade, as
we are running tasks intended to the overcloud and it
might not even exist.
This patch divides the script creation tasks used for
the undercloud from the ones used for the overcloud.

Change-Id: I35dfbe50d12b65a8d14f62410adea551e7584912
Closes-Bug: #1769107

[{'created': '2018-05-16 14:59:39.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken ceilometer variables

The option "ceilometer_service_adminurl" is not defined and not used in
the ceilometer role, however it has jinja that will error out if loaded
on it's own. This change removes that options and adds the required
options needed to render the used strings.

Change-Id: Ia747f400e8eca373b3f324d0ce09be803c5ed837
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix broken ceilometer variables

The option "ceilometer_service_adminurl" is not defined and not used in
the ceilometer role, however it has jinja that will error out if loaded
on it's own. This change removes that options and adds the required
options needed to render the used strings.

Change-Id: Ia747f400e8eca373b3f324d0ce09be803c5ed837
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Kubernetes: Add cluster delete dependents attribute

This patch add kubernetes cluster dependents, master cluster
record work cluster uuid to dependents.

Master cluster delete check dependents, if work cluster dependents
exist, the master cluster delete faild. kubernetes cluster
work cluster delete before master cluster delete.

Change-Id: Ie6f550f2187d629d396065269af9d4e9fba5acda
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Handle Docker rpm updates

The tasks were taken from OpenStack TripleO. They manage the case where
Docker needs to be updated. We'll first stop containers, stop docker
then update the rpm before making sure Docker is running again.

Change-Id: Ibde3d326b7e824fe09fafb9f46875b1e6739d299

copying the directories correctly.

This behaviour has been documented in the defaults file.

Change-Id: I6965e132674238727d69606464f2140ec42d6434
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-05-21 04:49:39.000000000', 'message': "Add trailing slash to copy files

for the target when is a directory. This change ensures we're copying

commit_message:
Add trailing slash to copy files

Without the trailing slash the sync task will create a nested directory
for the target when is a directory. This change ensures we're copying
copying the directories correctly.

This behaviour has been documented in the defaults file.

Change-Id: I6965e132674238727d69606464f2140ec42d6434
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

[{'created': '2018-05-19 04:22:17.000000000', 'message': "Update cleanup process and set a file prefix

The interface cleanup was generating a script that could be used to run
a cleanup whenever required. While this worked it would rapidly become
out of date, especially when multiple roles are calling this role. This
change adds a prefix which deployer can use to ensure the network
interface files are marked which will ensure we're limiting the
possibility of collisions.

The cleanup process will now use this prefix to search for and remove
any network interface file that matches the given prefix.

commit_message:
Update cleanup process and set a file prefix

The interface cleanup was generating a script that could be used to run
a cleanup whenever required. While this worked it would rapidly become
out of date, especially when multiple roles are calling this role. This
change adds a prefix which deployer can use to ensure the network
interface files are marked which will ensure we're limiting the
possibility of collisions.

The cleanup process will now use this prefix to search for and remove
any network interface file that matches the given prefix.

Change-Id: Ife5c179d27925cd2e71d3d086a731e6c13b12965
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Fix the test for unique IdP

The test that IdP and domain is unique constraint is wrong.
Keystone never support Idp:domain is 1:1.

This patch fixed the error in the test to make sure
Idp:domain is n:1.

Change-Id: I90a0ed677aa9d666a220bd2456dac336378cd3ba
Closes-bug: #1760843
